These indicate the future, and are practically the same as གི་ཡིན་, གི་རེད་, but with more of a sense of obligation. The forms རྒྱུ་ཡིན་ and ཡག་ཡིན་ are egophoric, whereas རྒྱུ་རེད་ and ཡག་རེད་ are neutral. The verb that precedes the auxiliary should be in the present-future.

  • དུས་སང་སློབ་གྲྭ་གསར་པ་རྒྱག་རྒྱུ་རེད། “Next year, we have to build a new school.”
  • གནས་ཚང་གཡར་རྒྱུ་རེད། “We have to find accommodation.”
  • ལམ་སེང་ཕེབས་ཡག་ཡིན་པས། “Do you have to leave immediately?”

In certain contexts, the forms རྒྱུ་ཡིན་ and རྒྱུ་རེད་ may also imply that something that ought to have been done already has yet to be accomplished. In this case, it may be translated by “hasn’t yet done X” or “has still to do X.” The verb preceding the auxiliary must be in the present-future.

  • ང་ཁ་ལག་ཟ་རྒྱུ་ཡིན། “I haven’t eaten yet.” (I’m about to eat.)
  • ཁོང་ཨ་ཅེ་ལྷ་མོ་ལྟ་རྒྱུ་རེད། “He has yet to go to the opera.”
  • ཁྱེད་རང་སྦྲག་ཁང་ལ་ཕེབས་རྒྱུ་རེད། “You still have to go to the post office.”
  • ང་དེ་རིང་གི་ཚགས་པར་ལྟ་རྒྱུ་ཡིན། “I haven’t yet read today’s newspaper.”

Note: The suffixes རྒྱུ་ and ཡག་ are usually interchangeable, but not in all cases. A distinction must be made between their function as nominalizing suffixes and as auxiliaries.

Nominalizing Suffixes:

  • The patient: རྒྱུ་ (future) and ཡག་ (present or future)
  • The instrument: ཡག་ but not *རྒྱུ་
  • The substance: རྒྱུ་ and ཡག་

Auxiliaries:

  • “One should not”: རྒྱུ་ཡོད་མ་རེད་ (but not *ཡག་ཡོད་མ་རེད་)
  • “Not yet”: རྒྱུ་རེད་ (but not *ཡག་རེད་)
  • The imminent future: རྒྱུ་རེད་ and ཡག་རེད་
  • “To have had the opportunity”: རྒྱུ་བྱུང་སོང་ and ཡག་བྱུང་སོང་

In each of these last four cases, the corresponding egophoric forms may also be used.
